review_detail: Visually, Moana is a gorgeous film.

The story is an echo of that ever-so-familiar journey in which young heroines become restless with the grind of their routines and wander beyond the borders of their world, usually against the wishes of strict parental figures.
A film with a plot is as simple as effective that recovers the tradition of the studio with the contribution of new technologies. [Full review in Spanish]
Disney's take on the oceanic myths of the Pacific Islands could go on to become an animated classic.
I have a soft spot for the gigantic, arrogant, avaricious crab named Tamatoa.
The Disney princesses are always a curious reflection of the changes on social paradigms. [Full review in Portuguese.]
It's strangely addictive.
Purposefully and persuasively continues the Disney tradition of tough, outspoken, and intrepid heroines without skipping a beat.
Brimming with gorgeous visuals, enchanting tunes and a captivating narrative, Moana chronicles the life-changing story of the eponymous South Pacific Islander.
A song score that's far weaker than the great animated musicals of the 1990s, this Disney princess film has all the charm one would expect from the Mouse House, without the feeling of urgency.
Who knew the Rock could belt out giddy showstoppers like an old Broadway ham?
I'd highly recommend taking the whole family to see Moana this weekend. It's exactly the kind of Disney movie we should be encouraging.
Moana ticks all the boxes required to make a great modern Disney princess movie and does so without ever feeling like it's a Disney princess movie.

Although the film lacks a swoony love story, its Freudian implications aren't particularly feminist, as Moana works to elevate the demigod's ego, diminished by the unreliablility of his damaged magical fishhook...
As for Moana, she makes for an inspiring centrepiece, the latest in a long line of Disney heroines that is simply unmatched by any other studio.
'Moana' is an enjoyable island getaway.
It's a visual marvel and has the reliably nice message one would hope for from the Mouse.
I highly recommend Moana to virtually any audience.
This will naturally prove a summery fave for the small-fry, even if the songs don't quite hit the heights and the final act feels a little flat.
Apart from those occasional dull patches, it is enjoyable.

It's a basic Point-A-to-Point-B adventure film, but with so much life, energy and emotion. It's perfectly cast, and the animation -- particularly the parts with the ocean in them, which is almost all of it -- is jaw dropping.
Pixar who?
Moana makes for a great role model for young children, especially girls.
Moana's indisputable saving grace is how good it looks - really, better than any other Disney movie to date, overflowing with lush, brazen beauty.
The film delivers the strong humor, well executed action, memorable music and lovable characters Disney has perfected in a delightful and lovely manner.
It feels less like a truly Polynesian story than it does a generic Disney story slotted into a new setting.
Moana is the celebration of uniqueness, culture, family and pure joy that we need right now.
Moana is an exceedingly joyful film and every bit the life-affirming catharsis many will be looking for this holiday season, particularly if you have a daughter during these times.
A crowd-pleasing oceanic musical with big tunes and beguiling characters, Moana is likely to thwack a big smile on your face.
So what if she'd rather be a sailor than a princess? Moana still rules.

The perfectly pleasurable "Moana" boasts vivid animation, a handful of catchy songs and a sweetly sunny disposition -- all suitable compensation for a story which is not particularly inspired or original.

Contemporary Disney at its finest - a vibrantly rendered adventure that combines state-of-the-art CG animation with traditional storytelling and colorful characters, all enlivened by a terrific voice cast.
Its cultural setting is fresh; its storytelling, less so. It navigates the reefs but it doesn't discover a whole new world.

Moana has a lot of the hallmarks of your classic Disney adventure - the goofy animal sidekicks, the feel-good messages - but its heroine is something new, a smart and fiery deviation from your standard European lovestruck princesses.

"Moana" keeps with the tradition that made Disney the leader in animated fairy and folk tales, and yet, showing a thoroughly modern touch, it's the first to do so without so much as suggesting a love interest.

Much to its credit, the screenplay makes Moana an interesting, self-actualized character. She's not waiting around for a prince, and there's no question that her gender will stand in the way of inheriting the title of chief.
Disney delivers another potent and primal piece of girl-powered mythmaking...

[Moana] is an excellent character with spirit, doubts, drive and a heck of a voice. She is a perfect addition to the roster of modern Disney heroines and one whom young girls will admire for years to come, princess or not.
Moana is a joy.

Temuera Morrison and Nicole Scherzinger are terrific voicing Moana's loving parents. Dwayne Johnson shines as Maui. First and foremost, though, is Auli'i Cravalho, winning the day and carrying the movie as the wonderful and quite lovable Moana.
A wonderful tale of the South Pacific, 'Moana' delivers oceans of family fun.
Enlightened and empowering, introducing a new Disney heroine.
In addition to the music, animation and storyline, Cravalho and Johnson are wonderful together.
If its heroine, despite her spunkiness, is a little milquetoasty, at least she doesn't pine for a guy-though how dumb is it that in 2016 we still have to compliment a kids' movie for that?
Released two weeks after you-know-what, it comes off as a battle cry, preaching hope when we need it most.
A call to adventure for a new generation.
Amusing characters and the most advanced CG to come down the pike, should make Moana a winner at the box office.
Disney's winning streak continues with Moana, a warm, friendly adventure destined for blockbuster success.
A wonderful and culturally-inspired fairy tale that captivates and thrills while shining the spotlight on a mythos rarely explored by Hollywood.
For the most part ... the movie feels more heartfelt than calculated, no small feat after decades of princesses, journeys, and "I want" songs.
Moana is another great musical from Disney, full of terrific characters and songs.
Actress Auli'i Cravalho, in her first job ever, soars as the voice of Moana

It's funny, joyful, and sweet, and yet down below, running beneath everything, is a sad counter-narrative about how the world always throws obstacles in your way, and how you could just turn your back and retreat.
Moana beats the drum of female empowerment for so many young girls who deserve it now more than ever.
I'll be real with you. It made me cry twice. Go see it.
Pure eye candy, but there's a journey here that holds attention, offering cultural flair, lively characterizations, and a charming way with myth and family. It's a charmer.
No, these things don't all blend together well, but if you can follow Moana's island society's lead and just roll with it, you'll enjoy them one by one.
The film is bright, busy, enjoyable, progressive without being insufferable.
"Moana" is a case of inspired visual and musical forms packaging wishy-washy substance. It's good generic comfort food, never cringeworthy, merely routine.
The film is richer for its attention to heritage, going far beyond surface aesthetics, building the foundation of "Moana" on the values and beliefs that make up this culture.
It's a traditional kind of Disney movie, a crowd pleaser with a few earworms on its soundtrack and an endearing pair of mismatched leads on an impeccably animated adventure.
It's so transporting it will have your kids begging you to book the next flight to the islands.
This is the best animated film I have seen since "WALL-E" (2008) and one of the best movies of the year.

Moana pays homage to Pacific Islanders by introducing us to a strong female character unlike any we've seen in mainstream films - a hero who is both smart and sympathetic, strong and compassionate, independent yet belongs to a group.
Moana would have been enormously entertaining regardless of when it came out, but its arrival at this particular moment in history gives it an added sense of significance-as well as inspiration.

a movie that follows the Disney playbook, for sure, but does it so well, even winking at it, that it is transcendentally delightful from start to finish...the best Disney animation to come down the pike since 2011's undervalued "Winnie the Pooh."
Compared to your average Disney princesses, Moana is neither selfishly rebellious nor simplistically innocent.
Tweaks the Disney animated template but sticks to its essentials, and does so nicely-it might not be revolutionary, but it's exuberantly familiar.
A wonderful mythology of demons and demigods. A heroine who embodies the bold spirit of her people. Another sweet, funny, exciting triumph from Disney.

That is Moana in a nutshell (or at least in a sea conch): smart about what it does, and easy on the eye, but at base the very Disney princess movie that it half-heartedly resists being - until, at least, its full heart is restored.
A dependably entertaining, visually dazzling riff on Polynesian folklore from the animators behind "The Little Mermaid" and "Aladdin."
A lively adventure driven by an independent heroine and the Broadway-ready songs of "Hamilton" creator Lin-Manuel Miranda. Gorgeous animation, too.

Cravalho shows spunk and a generically lovely voice, though she's saddled with assembly-line anthems Disney has done better elsewhere. Johnson has exuberance, deft timing and a passable singing voice.
Walt Disney Animation Studios, which arguably hasn't had a dud since "Meet the Robinsons" in 2007, continues its roll.
[A] lovely, reassuring hug of a movie ...
Moana has the power to uplift, inspire, and entertain.
Moana 's great heart and great humor actively subvert the violent, egocentric, macho mind-set that dominates so many popular stories.

Moana will be a big, happy hit, and I'll forever want to live in its glorious and vibrant environs. But hard as she may paddle, Moana can't quite get past the cluttered reef of merch and other branded interests that keeps her film penned in.
While Moana's story is rooted in the past, she's a modern heroine, a smart, resourceful leader who learns to find her own way.
"Moana" is a welcome step forward in its message and its look, and for young women characters in this type of film. It's a way without many satisfying twists and turns, but forward nevertheless.
Think of it as Disney's equivalent to Cars: an entertaining but average film that doesn't measure up to its predecessors.
Paying respect and homage to the Polynesian culture and its ancient mythology, the Walt Disney animation Moana is as culturally rich as it is entertaining.
Moana is a princess, but she's also tough and resilient, a hero worth singing about.
It's a playful, self-aware delight from beginning to end, a cinematic Broadway musical from John Musker and Ron Clements, who perfected the form in The Little Mermaid, Aladdin and Hercules.
A contemporary musical adventure that defies a few antiquated Disney conventions while exploiting a few others that still work.
A sunny, gorgeous emotionally heartfelt treat for a world desperately in need of a little comfort

Moana is pure vintage Disney. Evoking the fiber of the studio's classic films, Moana is more than worthy of being included and forming part of the pantheon of official Disney princesses. [Full review in Spanish]
Moana is solid "retro Disney" - a new film that embraces older ideas, themes, and narrative approaches.
You succumb to an enjoyable experience that splits the difference between mythology and merchandising.
...will fit nicely between your DVDs of Aladdin and The Little Mermaid.
"Moana" is a completely enchanting boost of warmth to the heart.
Whether or not Moana is the movie we need right now I can't say definitively, but I think it was the movie I needed. And I suspect I won't be alone in that feeling.
For holiday family entertainment, it does not get better than a fantastically lush Disney musical.

Disney continues its animation roll with Moana, a seafaring quest that sails past its one rocky patch with visual brilliance and several Broadway-ready songs, the latter conjured in part by Hamilton's Lin-Manuel Miranda.
Moana is smart, funny, thoughtful and full of heart - everything you'd hope to find in a chief, or a movie about one.
Moana looks lovely, and it gives us a princess we really haven't seen before. Those elements are surrounded, though, by too much that's all-too-familiar.
While the main themes of "Moana" are identity and self-discovery - familiar territory, to be sure - the film manages to enliven such well-traveled latitudes with a breeze as fresh as the islands.
A wonderful journey through the tales of a locale both inviting and intoxicating.
Moana's likable, dynamic characters pair well with the bright, blue seas in 3-D.
"Moana" might be [Walt Disney Animation Studio's] best since 1994's "The Lion King."
Lovable characters, memorable music make Disney film great.
There's not a prince or potential husband in sight; Moana's future is entirely defined by her leadership and ability to fend off the mansplaining know-it-all Maui. As messages go, we'll take it.
This Disney princess has no prince and the film is all the better because of it.
Moana is proof of one of the slightly less-repeated axioms of storytelling: It's OK to use familiar tropes as long as you use them well.
[Moana] has supercharged wit, eye-popping visuals featuring azure seas and glowing coral, spirited voice work from Auli'i Cravalho as Moana and Dwayne Johnson.
Say aloha to "Moana."
Perhaps the freshest pleasure lies in the spectacle of a Disney heroine who, for once, isn't beholden to any outside forces in pursuing her dreams.
Disney adds another best-of-2016 with Moana, the latest 'princess' film that addresses issues of identity and environment with grace, intelligence, and enthusiasm.
A progressive and rousing tale that becomes the crown jewel of the latest renaissance from the company.
If movies are meant to be a getaway, "Moana" is like a vacation.

What the story lacks in boldness ... is compensated in design and animation. Water, hair and gravity all flow naturally. The sunny island environment radiates happiness. And it does feature some clever moments of slapstick comedy.
If I was maybe thinking that the Disney "princess" formula needed to be retired, "Moana" suggests another direction.

There are no princes hanging around, no boys to really think about, no girly hang-ups or thingamabobs to fritter over, and no romantic subplots to distract from what's truly important: survival, independence, identity, self-belief.
A winning combination of action, comedy, musical, adventure and drama. The best family film of the holiday season!
Moana is a winning force, confidently standing alongside Ariel, Pocahontas, Mulan, and Anna.
Adults probably won't even mind if this becomes one of those high-rotation titles once the DVD/download option arrives. It is, like its title character, smart, quick-witted, inventive and melodious.
Disney should be applauded for adding more diversity to their Princess court. Those good intentions can only mask a few errors and can't bandage the clunky script.
In the tradition of "Brave," only significantly more watchable, this titled, strong-willed princess of a Pacific island doesn't need no stinkin' love interest to float her boat.
The computer animation is nothing short of amazing to behold. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Scary Stuff, etc. - also Available)
A great deal of imagination has clearly been pumped into the movie, ensuring that it's continually enjoyable to watch.
Story of Pacific Islander girl on a quest benefits from Dwayne Johnson's comic timing and a Lin-Manuel Miranda soundtrack
The Rock sings. A neglected culture gets its overdue closeup. Animation so lush you want to jump into the screen. Are you not entertained?
2016 has turned out to be quite a good year for animation, and Moana is a worthy addition to the honor roll.
It's a thrilling adventure that surges with sensational songs, lovable heroes, and messages that promote responsibility, forgiveness, bravery and resilience.
Doesn't fire entirely smoothly - its convoluted plot is a little hard to follow, for instance.
The film achieves what the best Disney animated features do: a sense of place that is refined and specific.
[Moana] is beautiful in more ways than I can tell, thanks to the brilliance of more animators than I could count.
Moana is a funny, heartfelt and richly-crafted hero's journey adventure that effectively puts a Disney spin on Southern Pacific culture
Moana recovers the spirit of Disney's unforgettable classic films and has a magical aspect thanks to modern technology. [Full review in Spanish]
One of the animation world's cinematic highlights for 2016.
As an animated film, Moana isn't close to ranking among Disney's best. But as a tropical postcard on the big screen, the animation couldn't be more spectacular and inviting.
Crowd-pleasing and upbeat, an ideal movie for families to see together over the holiday weekend.
a Disney cartoon doesn't need to be innovative to succeed; it just needs to hit the audience's heart and funny bone. 'Moana' does that well enough.
Moana is a movie of natural delights.
It would be going too far to say that Moana combines everything I enjoy about contemporary Disney with everything I dislike, but it's got quite a bit of both.

The animation is so flawless that the sailing sequences look as though they were filmed on location. The realistic motion of the water, as well as Moana's and Maui's long, wavy hair, is especially impressive.
The highly hummable score, by a team that includes Lin-Manuel Miranda, includes a big song for Moana, "How Far I'll Go," that should finally allow you to let go of Frozen's "Let It Go."
Frozen it ain't. Still, Moana looks fantastic.
Disney's digitally animated Moana, a Polynesian folk musical starring a plucky princess and a thousand-year-old demi-god, is beautiful to behold.
Moana functions as well as it does because the story team ultimately focused on finding everything about Disney stories that worked in 2016, and improving everything that didn't.
Moana may not be perfect, but you'll be humming its tunes and dreaming about its images long after leaving the theater.

Moana's female-empowerment message may not be as thoroughly worked out as it is in a movie like Whale Rider, but it is an enjoyable family film for the holidays that showcases the work of many actors of Polynesian descent.
An absolute delight, a lush, exuberant quest fable full of big musical numbers and featuring perhaps the most stunning visuals of any Disney film to date.
When it's cooking, Moana prepares tender, slip-off-the-bone meat on the tried-and-true bones of the Disney formula.
Singular in its imaginative, exotic visuals, which beg to be seen big and in the dark without distraction.
Amazing adventure, colour explosions and catchy songs. This is amazing.
With a gripping story fashioned from indigenous culture and a satisfying blend of the familiar and the knowing, Moana represents yet another triumph in the studio's impressive recent run.
A touch too familiar to qualify as a modern classic, Moana is a relentlessly entertaining spectacle rooted in authenticity with a talent pool so deep you can swim in it.
A film that while relevant and very modern, abides affectionately by the tropes of the genre at hand, depicting Polynesian culture with an air of enchantment and respect.
Brimming over with spectacle and visual inventiveness.
Moana isn't an instant classic on the level of Frozen, but it does continue Disney's strong multi-year run, thanks to great characters, gorgeous animation and a pretty strong story arc (Splice Today)
Gorgeously animated, heartwarming, exciting, and slyly self-aware.

Better than Finding Dory but not quite reaching the level of Zootopia, the latest Disney animated effort of 2016 adheres pretty much to the formula we've come to expect in recent years from the storied studio.
Moana is her own heroine, and that's such a strong show of empowerment for girls of all ages.
There is much to love about "Moana" --- the wonderful music, lush animation and, most of all, the stirring story.
Another traditional Disney animated flick packed with wonderful effects and Broadway-worthy music. Perfect for kids, adults and -- best of all -- families.
... a crowd-pleaser that's worthwhile for more than just boosting holiday toy sales.
With a captivating heroine, a startling array of gods and monsters, as well as a simply storming set of tunes, this brings together the best of Disney past and present in one knockout entertainment.
Moana offers first-class entertainment in the best Disney style.
It's a two-character show, and the stars deliver the goods with irresistible charm.
An amiable new animated musical that speaks to the tween-princess-sleepover demographic while tapping into Polynesian myths and making a modest, decently intentioned gesture at diversity.
Moana lacks the zest we associate with Disney's greatest creations.

This is Disney's way of having its formulaic cake and eating it, too: "We know what we're doing here, and we know that you know it, too. So please stop fretting and enjoy while the pieces fall into place."
No matter who wrote the songs, there was always going to be a line about listening to your 'inner voice' - it's pretty much Disney company policy.

The narrative is a fairly predictable hero's journey -- Maui even calls her "The Chosen One" -- but the movie is refreshing for its lack of a love interest; instead Moana learns how to chart her own course.

There could be umpteen charges of kitsch, political incorrectness and mongrelised cultural history. Yet this South Seas hurricane of a film blows us away, scattering our faculties and effects and substituting its own.
Despite Dwayne Johnson's solid scene-stealing, the wave-taming Moana gets a true hero's journey in this South Seas stunner.
Ultimately, it's this blend of character and quest -- infused throughout with an overriding warmth -- that makes Moana impossible to resist.
Although it lacks a little humor, this film has a young Polynesian who's courageously seeking her place in the world instead of a prince charming, . [Full review in Spanish]
The story is familiar, but the impressive animation and music should ensure that even the most jaded of viewers goes home with smiles on their faces.
Don't be surprised if you're singing -- badly -- all the way home.
Moana's animation and soundtrack are masterful, the best that the studio have done in two decades. [Full review in Spanish]

"Moana" sails straight and true, effortlessly, and with a great deal of joy and delight. It's perhaps not as clever or funny as this year's earlier Disney offering, "Zootopia," but it's wonderful in its own island way.

What impresses most here is the way the filmmakers combine the traditional Disney elements -- the sentimentality, the slapstick and the iridescent animation -- with a storyline rooted in South Sea island myth and culture.
We can now agree that Johnson is not only the Sexiest Man Alive but also our strongest, lifting Moana on his character's beefy shoulders, carrying it like other hits before. No movie left behind.
If you don't walk out of Moana feeling a little better about the world in general, check your pulse. You might be dead inside.

Maui isn't the only visual delight in Moana, but he's easily the standout. The lush 3-D depictions of the South Pacific actually make wearing the glasses and shelling out a few extra bucks worthwhile.
A film that reformulated the classic mythology of Disney princesses in stories of emancipation and female self-assertion. [Full review in Spanish]
The literal and metaphorical journey is predictable but fun, funny and beautiful. It's got a lovely score and a great tone, ye parents of wee daughters might finally be able to let Frozen go.
Dwayne Johnson does a wonderful job of voicing the conceited Maui, and if the storyline is not entirely satisfying, I could watch those gently undulating animated oceans forever.
It's no masterpiece, but it's all extremely pleasant, and in Moana herself, the film boasts Disney's most interesting and complex protagonist in several years.
In the next election, can I just vote Disney?
A gloriously exuberant and colourful adventure set in Polynesia which is both pleasingly traditional (there are songs and a plucky heroine!) and wittily modern (no handsome prince required).
There is much to relish in this animated Disney film, but I appreciated it as much for what it lacks as for what it contains.

Directors Ron Clements and John Musker here segue seamlessly into their first CG feature, embracing the malleable magic of digital animation while retaining the clear lines that underpinned their previous work.
It's a treat, for family audiences and musical theater geeks alike.
Mines proto-Polynesian Oceania culture's carefully researched legends, myths and traditions to joyfully bring us a feisty new Hollywood teenage rebel princess.
Both brilliant and breathtaking, "Moana" is sure to be the next Disney classic. The characters are beautifully established and the actors behind them are pitch perfect.

We never doubt for a second that Moana and Maui will complete their mission, but at least the story and animation have some lovely surprises in store along the way, especially in the spectacular climactic encounter.

This is a very solid Disney feature, that looks good in 3D, featuring excellent voice talents. The songs are O.K., but not up there with the Disney classics. This is a good, but not great Disney animated feature.
In Disney's latest refreshing take on the princess genre, Moana is a feisty, sea-voyaging chieftain's daughter without any pink satin in sight.
Visually stunning but narratively basic, Disney's Moana is nevertheless a highly enjoyable family movie that doesn't suffer too much from adhering to formula.

Moana offers something for every viewer, regardless of age. Adventure, humor, music and, of course, messages about identity, maturity, generational transition or the environment. [Full review in Spanish]
Disney's new animated gem and a reminder that possibly the company is currently going through the best years of its history. [Full review in Spanish]

Moana is a terrific Disney movie; vibrant, joyful, with great music and enthusiastic performances. It is steeped in tradition, both of its many legendary predecessors and the colourful culture it celebrates.
A nautical yarn that leaves lesser children's fare all at sea.
Truly wonderful stuff. If you don't enjoy this, I'd check your pulse as your heart must be missing.
Make[s] a familiar narrative feel like much more, and an entertaining feature ooze with thoughtful delight.
...one of Disney's least entertaining efforts in years...

Perhaps the most encouraging part of Moana's feminism is its subtlety. It presents female agency as nothing out of the ordinary - it doesn't comment on it, there is no patriarchy she's fighting back against and there's no love story.
Moana is a toe-tapping, heart-stealing adventure packed with laughs and featuring a kick-ass princess with nary a love interest on the horizon.
A gentle, sun-soaked mythological Disney romp around the volcanic islands of Polynesia.
Moana (Auli'i Cravalho) could be the most fully developed royal Disney heroine yet.
Fun and a visually stunning.
It could be a great work similar to Kubo and the two strings, but it lacks true innovation preventing it to transcend. [Full review in Spanish]
Moana is Disney at its dreamy, catchy, heart-bursting best.
A film that has a strong message that fits perfectly to our times, and that everybody will enjoy. [Full review in Spanish]
... Moana is visually beautiful and narratively engaging.
We are so spoilt by the amazing achievements of animation we hardly notice when something special comes along, unless we look out for it. Moana makes us look
Moana is a gorgeous offering by Disney that uses the magnificence of our planet to tell a simple but effective girl meets demigod sea-set story.
A film that is far from being a disaster but at this point in the game, one expects something more from the Disney. And this time it didn't manage to meet expectations. [Full review in Spanish]
Well, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

Though not without a few flat spots, this intelligently scripted and accessible fare is blessed with spellbinding marine visuals and esoteric earworms aplenty from composer-of-the-moment Lin-Manuel Miranda.
What works best about Moana are its moments of cultural peculiarity.
While Moana is the title character, it's Dwayne Johnson's Maui who steals the show - because he can.
Though Moana delivers plucky entertainment and some colorful characters, it plays the narrative too safely by relying on commonplace machinations.
Moana is one of Disney's best films, and undoubtedly one of the most beautiful and emotional of the year. [Full review in Spanish]
